keyTakeAways: A major road collision on the Kampala-Gulu Highway killed 63 people, all from vehicles involved in a head-on crash during overtaking maneuvers.
The accident occurred when two buses attempting to overtake a truck and car collided head-on, highlighting dangerous driving practices.
The Kampala-Gulu Highway is one of Uganda’s busiest roads, linking the capital to northern Uganda, making such accidents particularly impactful.
Uganda’s road fatality rate has risen from 4,534 in 2022 to 5,144 in 2024, indicating a worsening road safety crisis.
The Red Cross described the victims as left bleeding with broken limbs, emphasizing the severity and human cost of the incident.
Police are urging motorists to avoid dangerous overtaking, identifying it as a leading cause of crashes in the country.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major head-on collision occurred on the Kampala-Gulu Highway in Uganda just after midnight, resulting in the deaths of 63 people—all occupants of the vehicles involved. The crash happened during overtaking maneuvers by two buses attempting to pass a truck and car, which led to a fatal head-on collision. The incident underscores a growing road safety crisis in Uganda, with road fatalities rising from 4,534 in 2022 to 5,144 in 2024. The Red Cross reported victims with severe injuries, including broken limbs, and emphasized the horrific nature of the scene. Police have issued a strong warning against dangerous overtaking, identifying it as a primary cause of road crashes in the country. The Kampala-Gulu Highway, one of Uganda’s busiest routes, remains a high-risk corridor for such accidents.
title: Collision on highway near Uganda’s capital kills 63 people
